title: Enforce FK constraint between conversions.campaign_id and ad_campaigns.campaign_id
description:
Implement and deploy a formal foreign key constraint from conversions.campaign_id to ad_campaigns.campaign_id in the production database schema for the e_commerce analytics environment. Steps:
1) Profile current data to identify orphaned conversions.campaign_id values (not present in ad_campaigns.campaign_id) and quantify impact.
2) Clean or remediate invalid campaign_id values (e.g., map to valid campaigns, mark as unknown, or remove invalid rows based on business rules).
3) Update the DDL to add the FK constraint with appropriate ON DELETE/ON UPDATE behavior (typically RESTRICT or CASCADE based on marketing requirements).
4) Apply the change first in a staging environment, run regression tests on ETL/ELT jobs and marketing attribution reports, then roll out to production during a controlled deployment window.
5) Coordinate with marketing and data teams to communicate the new constraint and its implications for upstream data producers.

title: Document conversions–ad_campaigns relationship and attribution rules in data dictionary
description:
Create comprehensive documentation for the relationship between conversions.campaign_id and ad_campaigns.campaign_id in the central data dictionary for the e_commerce analytics stack. The documentation should include:
1) Business definition of a "conversion" and a "campaign" in this domain (e.g., purchase, add-to-cart, sign-up; paid search, display, social, etc.).
2) Technical definition of the relationship (1:N or N:1), including the FK mapping, cardinality, and any known edge cases (e.g., legacy campaigns, test campaigns).
3) Attribution logic used in marketing analytics (e.g., last-click, first-touch, multi-touch rules) and how conversions are linked to campaigns in reporting.
4) Data freshness and latency expectations for both tables and how that may affect attribution accuracy.
5) Example queries and report usage patterns (e.g., standard campaign performance dashboards) and guidance for analysts on how to correctly join these tables.
6) Ownership and contact points for schema changes (data owner, marketing ops).
Publish this documentation in the agreed knowledge repository (e.g., Confluence, internal data catalog) and link it from the schema metadata.

title: Implement automated referential integrity monitoring for conversions–campaigns link
description:
Set up ongoing data quality checks to monitor referential integrity between conversions.campaign_id and ad_campaigns.campaign_id, with alerts when containment drops below 95%. Implementation details:
1) Define a daily (or intra-day) job that computes:
   - Containment: share of conversions.campaign_id values that exist in ad_campaigns.campaign_id.
   - Orphan rate: percentage and count of conversions rows with invalid campaign_id.
2) Implement checks in the existing data quality framework (e.g., dbt tests, Great Expectations, or custom SQL checks) and store historical metrics for trend analysis.
3) Configure alerting thresholds (e.g., warning at 97%, critical at 95%) and integrate with the team’s notification channels (Slack/Email/PagerDuty).
4) Tag this check as "marketing_attribution_critical" so issues are prioritized by on-call data/engineering teams.
5) Provide a simple dashboard or report for data stewards and marketing ops to review historical integrity trends and investigate spikes in orphaned conversions.
